bibl.title: Letter from John W. Hart to Philip Showalter Hench, October 27, 1944

div1.p: Hart informs Hench that he has become Vice President and General Manager of Winthrop Products. The article on Building No. 1 was written by the medical director of their Cuban organization, not by Hart. However, Hart does plans on writing an article about Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from John W. Hart to Philip Showalter Hench, October 27, 1944
div1.opener:
WINTHROP PRODUCTS INC.
Pharmaceuticals Developed by Science and Dedicated to the Physician
350 HUDSON STREET
NEW YORK 14, NEW YORK
WINTHROP
N
W
E
S
October 27, 1944
Lt. Col. Philip S. Hench, M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service
Army & Navy General Hospital
Hot Springs National Park, Ark.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
It was indeed a pleasure to receive your letter of
the 16th of October concerning the Annotated Bibliography on Penicillin.
I am having copies of both series sent you by Winthrop Chemical Company.

Since last we met, considerable change has come
over the scene. The firm, “Winthrop Products Inc.” was organized in
1941 for Latin American business and yours truly is now Vice President
and General Manager of this organization. I do not get around to
seeing the chaps at Winthrop Chemical as often as I used to but I
will make a note to get you the Annotated Bibliography.

The article on Building No. 1 of yellow fever
fame was written by the medical director of our Cuban organization,
Dr. Arturo Ros and his interest was aroused by yours truly after he
had introduced him to Moran and had accompanied the two of them first,
to the site of the Division Hospital at Camp Colombia and then to the
site of Camp Lazear and Building No. 1. I of course knew that the
porch was not a part of the original building and know that there are
one or two other discrepancies in his article. Had I had the oppor-
tunity of reading the proofs before its publication, there are
several corrections I could have made.

I am planning, however, to write an article on
the site of Camp Lazear and a correction, at least in the minds of
the medical profession in Cuba, of the beliefs that Camp Lazear existed
at the site of the old tree or, location of the Division Hospital.

With reference to the building and the memorial
to be erected at the site of the building, I look forward to having a
part in this when the time comes and I believe that you are quite
correct in having a protecting frame placed over the building as it
now stands. I am wondering however, if it would not be better to
P.O. BOX 90 CANAL STREET STATION
CABLE ADDRESS “WINCOX”
WINTHROP PRODUCTS INC.
- 2 -
make a more substantial protection than a wooden frame. The recent hurricane
has left me with some fears as to the safety of the building and I certainly
hope that nothing has happened.

We have our permanent organization in Cuba with Manager,
Assistant Manager, Medical Director, detailmen, etc. and if any of them
can be of service at any time to pinchhit for Mr. Moran or to assist him
in any way, please let me know. I have such an intense interest in the
entire project that I have taken a more or less personal view on the
protection of the building and will, as stated above, do anything in my
power to see that it is properly guarded.

I shall obtain a half dozen copies of the article as it
appeared in our Horizontes Médicos and if you should at any time care
for any copies of the photographs which I made and, I believe, gave to you,
I shall be only too glad to have enlargements printed.

With the kindest personal regards and looking forward to
seeing you in the near future and with best wishes to Mrs. Hench, I am
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, John W. Hart jwh-jn
P.S. Do you expect to attend the Southern Medical at St. Louis? If so,
I should like to see you. I shall be stopping at the Missouri Athletic
Club.
